Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or sources to back up the assertion that the fictional speech in "The Crown" was derived from real utterances by John F. Kennedy.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the fictional speech was derived from real utterances by Kennedy, when in reality, only certain phrases and lines were taken from Kennedy's actual speeches.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the fictional speech was not taken word-for-word, in its entirety, from any particular speech made by Kennedy.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation could be that the writers of "The Crown" used historical events and speeches by Kennedy as inspiration for the fictional speech, but did not directly derive it from real utterances.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear and concise explanation of the extent to which the fictional speech in "The Crown" was derived from Kennedy's real utterances.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the fictional speech in "The Crown" accurately represents the views and words of John F. Kennedy, without considering the creative liberties taken by the show's writers.
Understate: The claim may understate the extent to which the fictional speech in "The Crown" was influenced by Kennedy's actual speeches, as it only mentions that "several lines" were taken word-for-word.
